Some hundreds of years later testators were enabled by enactments of Constant' S, Λα). 339, and Theodosius 11, Α.1).·439, to give legacies in any words t ey chose, whether Greek or Latin, Cod. 6. 37. 21 3 6. 23. 21. 6. Justinian’s own regulations, mentioned in this and the following sectionS, assimilated the civil law bequest (legatum) so far as was possible to fideicommissa, the nature of which will appear from Tits. 23 and 24 inf. Any legal superiority which either had possessed over the other was in future to be common to both, and the object os a bequest, whether technically a legatum or a fidei- commissum, was to be recoverable by the beneficiary by the most ap- propriate remedy, real or personal. The legatee acquired a real right to the res legata in every case where it belonged to the testator, and in no other, unless indeed the testator himself expressed a contrary intention, Cod. 6. 43. 1 3 he acquired a personal right against the heir in every case, and this was secured by a statutory hypotheca, first given by Justinian himself, over everything which the person on whom the legacy or fideicommissum was charged had himself received from the inherit- ance, Cod. 6. 43. 2.
